0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Amenorrhea, Secondary: 2.5-10 mg ORALLY daily for 5-10 days during the second half of the theoretical menstrual cycle (after endometrium has been adequately primed with estrogen); adapt dosage to specific indications and therapeutic response of individual patient
  • Dysfunctional uterine bleeding: 2.5 to 10 mg ORALLY daily for 5 to 10 days during the second half of the theoretical menstrual cycle (after endometrium has been adequately primed with estrogen); adapt dosage to specific indications and therapeutic response of individual patient
  • Endometriosis: initial, 5 mg ORALLY daily for 2 weeks
  • Endometriosis: maintenance, increase dose by 2.5 mg per day every 2 weeks until 15 mg daily is reached; administer for 6-9 months or until breakthrough bleeding demands temporary termination; adapt dosage to specific indications and therapeutic response of individual patient

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: Safety and effectiveness in children not established

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Amenorrhea, Secondary
  • Dysfunctional uterine bleeding
  • Endometriosis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
In vitro fertilization; Adjunct

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Arterial thromboembolic disease, active or recent (within 12 months)
  • Carcinoma of the breast, known, suspected, or history of
  • DVT or pulmonary embolism, active or history of
  • Hypersensitivity to norethindrone acetate or any component of the product
  • Liver disease or impaired liver function
  • Pregnancy
  • Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding
  • Use as a diagnostic test for pregnancy

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- Use cautiously in patients with risk factors for arterial vascular disease or VTE
  • -- Fluid retention may occur; monitoring recommended in those with epilepsy, migraines, and cardiac or renal dysfunction
  • Endocrine and Metabolic:
  • -- Effects on lipid and carbohydrate metabolism have been reported; monitoring recommended for diabetic and hyperlipidemic patients
  • Ophthalmic:
  • -- Visual abnormalities may occur; permanent discontinuation may be required
  • Psychiatric:
  • -- Worsening or recurring depression has been reported; monitoring recommended and discontinuation may be necessary
  • Reproductive:
  • -- Adequately evaluate if undiagnosed vaginal bleeding occurs

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Edema
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea
  • Reproductive:Breast tenderness, Irregular periods
Serious
  • Hematologic:Deep venous thrombosis, Thromboembolic disorder
  • Ophthalmic:Optic neuritis

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Norethindrone acetate is a synthetic and active progestin with twice the weight-based potency of norethindrone. In an estrogen-primed endometrium, it stimulates secretory changes.

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• Protein binding, Albumin: 61%
  • Protein binding, Sex hormone-binding globulin: 36%
  • Vd: Approximately 4 L/kg

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Liver: Extensive via reduction then conjugation
  • Sulfate metabolites: Unknown
  • Glucuronide metabolites: Unknown

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Renal: Detected, as metabolites
  • Fecal: Detected, as metabolites
  • Total body clearance: 0.4 L/hr/kg

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
take exactly as directed at intervals not exceeding 24 hr

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• Improvement in amenorrhea, endometriosis, or abnormal uterine bleeding indicates efficacy
  • Fluid retention; in patients with conditions that may be affected by this
  • Worsening or recurring depression
  • Effects on lipid or carbohydrate metabolism; in patients with diabetes or hyperlipidemia

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
PROGESTINS
OVERDOSE: Rarely do acute ingestions result in obvious clinical manifestations. CHRONIC: Most adverse effects are related to chronic or high-dose therapy. Headache, dizziness, irregular menses, mastalgia, bloating, depression, decreased libido, cholestatic jaundice, hepatitis, oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea and thromboembolism may occur with chronic therapy.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
PROGESTINS
  • Support: Single acute overdoses will seldom result in toxicity. Supportive treatment is adequate in most situations.
  • Decontamination: Gastric decontamination is probably only necessary after very large ingestions or with toxic coingestants; administer activated charcoal in these cases.
  • Monitoring of patient: CHRONIC TOXICITY: Discontinue medication and monitor for signs of toxicity and treat symptomatically. Obtain a baseline CBC and hepatic and renal function tests in symptomatic patients.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
PROGESTINS
Toxicity is unlikely following an acute overdose. There are insufficient data reported in the literature to assess the range of toxicity in terms of mg/kg ingested.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient that withdrawal bleeding may occur within 3 to 7 days after discontinuing drug therapy.
  • This drug may cause edema, acne, chloasma, change in weight, headache, depression, abnormal menstruation, breakthrough bleeding, tender or swollen breasts, or scanty vaginal bleeding.
  • Tell patient to report signs/symptoms of thromboembolic/thrombotic disorder or optic neuritis (sudden partial or complete loss of vision, sudden onset of proptosis, diplopia, or migraine).
